newsitem.title: RUSSIA: AGROKHLEB-Russia spring wheat sowing may be record.
newsitem.headline: AGROKHLEB-Russia spring wheat sowing may be record.

text.p: The following is a direct contribution from SovEcon Ltd, an independent research organisation specialising in agricultural production and trade in the former Soviet Union.
RUSSIAN AREA SOWN TO SPRING WHEAT LIKELY TO SET NEW RECORD

MOSCOW, May 23 - Assuming normal development of the spring sowing campaign, SovEcon expects that Russia's total spring wheat area may set a new record and fall in the range of 16.9-17.4 million hectares (16.4 million hectares in 1996).
At this early stage, SovEcon's forecast for Russia's total wheat output in 1997 is in the range of 35-38 million tonnes (34.9 million tonnes in 1996).
An increased sowing area, combined with good development of winter wheat plantings, may boost total wheat output in 1997.
But unfavorable weather in May has delayed spring wheat plantings in the Urals.

Still, good weather continues to help the spring wheat campaign in Siberia, particularly in Western Siberia. In the major Siberian wheat-producing areas (Altai, Omsk, Novosibirsk), sowings are at 1995's near-record level.
Early spring wheat sowings there may result in higher yields in spite of the losses which often obtain from adverse weather during harvesting.
Despite rainy weather in Povolzhsk, farmers are likely to increase spring wheat plantings there due to strong domestic demand for milling wheat.
